rating_criteria.description: TBI is rated based on residual symptoms in THREE areas: cognitive, behavioral/emotional, and physical. The overall rating is determined by the HIGHEST level of impairment in any of the three areas.

levels.description: Mild impairment - complains of memory, attention, concentration, or executive function problems, but objective evidence of impairment is not demonstrated
Moderate impairment - objective evidence of moderate impairment in memory, attention, concentration, or executive function
Severe impairment - objective evidence of severe impairment in memory, attention, concentration, or executive function
Total impairment - unable to function independently
Mild impairment - occasional irritability, mild anxiety
Moderate impairment - increased irritability, impaired judgment, social difficulties
Severe impairment - marked irritability, aggression, or emotional instability
Total impairment - danger to self or others

physical_neurological.name: Physical/Neurological Dysfunction
physical_neurological.description: Headaches, dizziness, balance, fatigue, sensory symptoms

levels.description: Mild impairment - occasional symptoms that do not interfere significantly with functioning
Moderate impairment - symptoms that moderately interfere with functioning
Severe impairment - symptoms that severely interfere with functioning
Total impairment - constant symptoms preventing all functioning

levels.criteria: Diagnosed TBI with no residual symptoms (Level 0 in all three areas)
Level 1 impairment in one or more areas - mild subjective symptoms not objectively demonstrated
Level 2 impairment in one or more areas - moderate objective evidence of impairment
Level 3 impairment in one or more areas - severe objective evidence of impairment causing deficiencies in most areas
Total impairment in one or more areas - unable to function independently

symptoms_checklist.description: TBI residual symptoms documented by examiner

cognitive_symptoms.symptom: Complete inability to recall recent events

diagnostic_criteria.description: TBI diagnosis requires documentation of traumatic event and residual symptoms

criteria.name: Traumatic Event
criteria.description: History of head injury or blast exposure with one or more of the following

criteria.name: Residual Symptoms
criteria.description: Current symptoms in one or more areas

criteria.name: Nexus
criteria.description: Current symptoms are at least as likely as not related to the traumatic event

secondary_conditions.description: TBI commonly causes conditions that may warrant separate ratings

tips_for_veterans: Document ALL head injuries and blast exposures in service, even 'minor' ones
Describe symptoms based on your WORST days, not average or good days
List all compensations you use: alarms, lists, GPS, family help
Have family members write statements about changes they've observed
Don't appear too 'put together' - this masks your actual deficits
Mention cognitive fatigue and how long you can concentrate
Document headache frequency, severity, and duration specifically
Consider separate claims for headaches, tinnitus, and other residuals
Explain what you could do before vs. what you cannot do now
If you've lost jobs due to TBI symptoms, provide documentation
common_mistakes: Appearing too 'functional' due to compensations (lists, alarms, GPS)
Not mentioning all head trauma incidents (cumulative damage matters)
Not bringing family/buddy statements documenting changes
Performing well on cognitive tests on a 'good day'
Forgetting to mention sleep, fatigue, and light/noise sensitivity
Not explaining functional impact on work and daily life
